page.lettertext:
fol.77r
May it please yo
r
good L: By yo
r
l
re
of
e 24 of Sept
I finde her
Ma
tie
discontented, as if I had not bin
so carefull, as imported her service, to calle for an
answear from
e
States.
But my trust is in yo
r
L.
for informing her Hig
es
w
at
kinde of instance I
have used, as all my l
res
will declare it. And yet
I never thought it meete, to trouble yo
r
L. with
reporte of all my travels and endevors, at every
tyme in particular,
at I went about my businesse.
I hope her Hig
es
wilbe pleased to give me credit
in this case,
at I may reape some other fruites
then pensivenesse and grief, for my painefull
solicitation. And where againe I am enjoyned
to proceede w
t
out admitting any dilatorie an-
swear, I protest unto yo
r
L. I knowe not in
e
worlde, howe to doe it more effectually then I have
put in triall, having done in
at behalf both in
publicke and in privat, as much as is possible:
and more by much then is expressed in any point
as by other insinuations of danger to
e Contrey: in
so much as I have doubted in myne owne privat
judgement, whether I kept in
at Decorum, in re-
gard of
e dignitie and state of her Ma
tie
to in-
sist so earnestly, so often, so manie sundrie wayes
w
t
a people of this condition and so muche bound
unto her Hig
es
. And therfore not prevailing
with so great importunitie I could wade no
further with them, but certefie by l
res
, howe I
founde their dispositions. But sins
e receat
of yo
r
L. l
re
,
e
Councell of Esate
being come home
to
e Hage, upon
e writing of
e States, I laboured
w
at
I could to procure their advise to be present-
ly given: but getting notice underhand, that
their drifte was altogether, to send unto her Ma
tie
(as I have alwayes thought they would) to
cutte of all occasions of further delayes, I lette
them flatly understand and withall I made
fol.77v
it knowen to
e College of
e States,
at if so be they
had no meaning to satisfie her Hig
es
, but would
happelie determine to send some Deputies unto
her to deliver their excuses, they should alter
at intent, and keepe their Deputies at home
for so I had bin willed to signifie unto them.
This was taken muche to harte,
at her Ma
tie
would refuse in a cause of
at moment to give
them the hearing, and both
e States and
e
Councell have consulted very often, for divers
dayes together, w
at
course to take upon it.
For to forbeare to send at all, they thought it
might be taken for a weake resolution, sith they
could not by theyr l
res
make so cleere a demon-
stration of their want of readie meanes, to
give her Ma
tie
contentment, and to prevent
therw
t
al
e effectes of her displeasure, as by
e
verbals of those,
at might be purposely sent about
it; whome they hoped that her Hig
es
, upon their
suite in
at behalfe, would be willing to admitte.
And yet to send upon presumption when they
had bin by me forewarned to refraine, and so
perhaps when they came to be rejected of her
Ma
tie
they thought it would be caried over all partes
of Christendome, and moove
e multitude heere,
who might thinke they were foresaken, to accept
of such conditions as
e Peacemakers offer. Muche
a doe there hath bin as I am told by some among
them, and yet I see it is uncertaine, when, or
howe they will conclude; albeyt by all conjecture
I thinke within these 3 dayes they will make some
what of it. But because it is in doubt and
e tyme
may seeme long sins I writte unto yo
r
L. having
bin for these 20 dayes put in hope from daye to day,
of some final resolution, I thought it needfull
e
while to informe yow what hath passed; wherin
I see no disposition (howsoever they may happen
to be secretly minded) to condescend to any portion
fol.78r
of present remboursement: but onely to make knowen,
that this paiment is demanded before
e daye, and
out of season, for
at
e warres are not ended, and
e Contrey hath no meanes, which will also be
e
teno
r
, by
at which I can yet ghesse of their
l
res
and message, for
at I thincke they will
agree upon
e one or
e other. It should
seeme by a clause in yo
r
L. l
re
,
at you understoodde
certaine wordes w
ch
I had used in my l
res
of
e
27 of Au
g
and 11 of Sep
t
of a newe, and an
other kinde of Treatie
as if
e States had a purpose to renewe the Treatie
w
t
her Ma
tie
, whereas I
understood it of a newe agreement altogether,
w
t
other newe conditions: as to signifie to yo
r
L.
wherupon I writte it; I had put
e question in
co
m
unication to some two or three heere, why
they made it nowe so hard, to finde money for
her Ma
tie
if they meant to make paiment of
these Annual remboursements, w
t
entertaining
so many English, as my ouverture delivered at
my last co
m
ing home? To this
e parties made
answear w
t
whome I dealt in
at mater, That
it was not possible to cause
e
Provinces
to acknow-
ledge
at
e terme of
e Contract is expired, when
e wordes and
e texte are so plaine against it,
and
at they would not be induced to make any
restitution, as for debt already dewe, but by proposing
unto them some other forme of Treatie, they might
have bin intreated by good handling of their
humors, to cancel
e old, and to persuaded indi-
rectly, to have included in a newe certaine yerly
paiments, for her Hig
es
contentation, in regard
of her former charges. Heereupon it was
at I
did insinuat, that as farre as I could learne,
if any thing were obtained, it must come by
e
meanes of a newe Accord. But of any resolution
either taken or intended to be taken about it, I
am utterly ignorant. For as occasions may be
given, if they chance to send their Deputies,
fol.78v
they are lyke enough in secret to conclude other maters
as their usual maner is, and also afterwardes, in
England, to autorise them to deale, as any motion
to their liking shall happen to proceede from her
Ma
tie
or themselves. When I presse them somew
at
neere in privat conversation to tell me, howe they
can prevent
e subversion of their State, if her
Ma
tie
should protest, and withdrawe her assistance
their answeares savoureth altogether of a desperat
moode. Loth, they say, they would be to contest
with her Hig
es
and will shunne it, as they may,
in all duetifull sort, that
e Enemie may not
triumph, and turne it to his benefitte: but if
she force them unto it, by her publicke protesta-
tions, they have but too much to alleage, both to
justefie themselves in
e sight of
e worlde, and
to notifie to all men, w
t
what patience they
have boaren the breaches of
e contract, exceeding
greatly to their prejudice. And if withall she
will proceede to deprive them of her aide, they must,
and will provide to trust unto themselves, and to
suche helpes as God shall send, it having ever bin
their destinie, to defend their libertie and rightes
w
t
adversitie and troubles. But if otherwise then
well should befalle their Estate, it would beseeme
but oversoone,
at
Englandes
staffe is next
e doore.
I calle to mynde many tymes that her Ma
tie
in her speeches of
e affaires of these Contreys, hath se-
med often so to build upon
e affections of this people
as if
e Generalitie were more addicted to content
her, then this assemblie of their Deputies: and
at
e inhabitants of
e Townes might be drawen
by remonstrance to refourme and disavowe
e
dealinges of their delegats. This was so out of
question at
e making of
e Contract, and so continued
somew
at
after, untill they grewe out of liking with
some courses
at were held by some Ministers of her
Ma
tie
, and reduced their Estate to some better
fol.79r
forme of gouvernment. But for these 6 or 7 yeares:
I have found
e people very willing, to be guided by
their Deputies, who are also very warie, to knowe
howe farre they may presume. For though somew
at
sometymes be done by their Deputies against their
humors and opinions, yet it is but very seldome in
maters of moment: and I could never yet observe
that there was anie thing controlled or counter-
manded by
e people, that they had once ordained.
Which is the patience they will use, for preservation
of their union. Wherof I thought it not amisse to
touche a worde unto yo
r
L. if happelie some course
of proposing maters to
e Co
m
ons, should seeme
expedient for her Ma
tie
. The losse of
e Towne
of
Cambray
doth minister muche mater of newe
discourses in this Contrey, very many men disliking
at carelesse dealing of
e King, and misdoubting
least their succo
rs
will prove but ill bestowed:
in so much
at I perceave, unles
at somew
at
with
speede be atchieved, by
e King for
e advancement
of their cause, he shall finde them for heereafter
a great deale streiter laced in assisting him w
t
money. But yet this last Absolution doth keepe
their headdes busied above all other maters; as
that w
ch
they account will entyce him ere be long
to some attonement w
t
e Spaniard, and drawe
this Contrey shortly after into notable inconveni-
ence. What opinion
e Enemie conceaveth of a
Peace, your L. may conjecture by
e l
re
heerw
t
of
e
Marquis of Havre
to
e Count of Berghe, which
was lately intercepted, and sent us from
e Campe.
Intercepted
letter from the
Marquis of Havre
I have also seene an other to
e self same
effect, from a chief man of
Brussels,
to a privat
person heere. It is given out by
e marquis,
and is confermed by our co
m
on occurrences,
at
Co
m
issionners appointed by
e Chamber of Spyres,
to come hither to mediate an accord w
t
e Spani-
ard, are nowe in consultation at
Frankfort
or
Collen,
Many men heere suspect, that for
e
fol.79v
furtherance of this Peace, the release of their gooddes
and Shippes is artificially dallied of, till
e coming
of
e Cardinal of Austriche, and
e
P. of Orenge
(who
are expected very shortlie)
at they may be
e offerers
of
at special grace and favo
r
, and persuade both
e owners and others by their meanes, to listen so
muche
e sooner to their desired Pacification.
I have enquired very harde, to knowe
e au-
tor of
at Frenche discourse, w
ch
I sent to my
L. of
Essex
: but no bodie heere can tell it for certaine;
albeyt it is fathered by
e most upon
Lipsius,
who
hath handled by reporte that subject in a l
re
, and
at doth
savor altogether his stile, and forme of writing.
There is intelligence come from
Andwerp,
at
e Indian
Fleete arryved at S
t
Lucar in
Spaine,
e 7 of Sep
t
with
10 millions. I thinke yo
r
L. hath heard
at
Haranguieres
e Gouvernor of
Breda,
by whome
Huy
was surprised in February last, hath attempted
e
lyke upon
e Towne of
Lier,
a very strong place in
e
Dukedome of
Brabant,
about two Leagues from Andwerp
where he and his troupe of 7 or 8 hundred, of w
ch
many were disguised in boores apparell, and came
in earlie in a morning, on an Oxe market daye,
seasing on a gate, possessed p
nt
ly
e Towne, the
Munition howse,
e market place, and every
gate saving one, w
ch
they kept without impeach-
ment, from 5 in
e morning till 3 in
e afternoone
and then for want of good order,
e soldeirs falling
to
e spoyle,
e bourghers tooke armes, and others
soldiers to
e nomber of 2000 came from Andwerp,
Malines,
and
Herentals,
w
ch
slewe as we thinke
500 of ours, and put
e rest to flight. And thus o
r
happe is all this yere to come home by weeping
crosse, in all
e attempts we take in hand.
In effect, what w
t
that, and
e plottes that are
casting to enforce a Pacification, and the courses
held in
France,
with those other considerations,
which I enlarged to yo
r
L.
e 17 of Au
g
together
with
e mater of my message unto them,
fol.80r
they are so muche amased, and so fearfull least
e people
should beginne to take a head, and revolt in some
quarter, which, they doubt, may drawe after
e bodie
of their confederacie, as I never sawe them for any
thinge, albeyt I have bin heere in dyvers great
astonishments, so abjectly minded, as they are at
this p
nt
. And yet in my opinion there doth
nothing prognosticat so great a danger towardes,
as
e grudges and discordes betweene Province
and Province, in contributing their portions,
and
e envies and dislykes
at are secretly kindled,
but smouthered for
e tyme, among
e chiefest of
e Contrey, which may occasion on
e suddaine a
disunion of
e States, when so many other causes
concurre to helpe it forwardes. Nowe they see
and complaine of
e want of a P. Orenge, or of some
suche able person, to compose these couvert quarels,
to hold
e Provinces together in good correspondence,
to animat
e people in these cases of desaster, and
to propose in other accidents,
e meetest meanes to
be embroved for
e benefitte of
e Contrey.
Count
Maurice
is young, and voide of experience, not
deliting to meddle with affaires of
e State, and in
a ma
n
er among
e rest there is equalitie altogether:
so as none will undertake to be
e autors of a pro-
ject in a businesse of importance, lest it should
not speede aright, unles it may be some one, who
by reason of his place, as Advocat of
Holland,
hath
by Nature very pregnant to plotte and devise, so
as having bin fortunat in
e issue of some counsailes,
beyond all expectation, he hath caried away
e
credit in contriving and managing most maters
of
e State. Howbeyt his coequals mutter at it
muche, and his betters so disdaine it, as if his
fortune chance to faile him, it will quicklie goe
amisse w
t
his credit and countenance. And
thus the weight of this cause is
e occasion of
my length, and of so many points inserted.
fol.80v
XVII.71.
Copie of my Letter to My L. T
re
r 19 Oc
t
1595
M
r
Bodley
of which I thought it not impertinent to make
some litle mention, beseeching you most hum-
bly to make relation to her Ma
tie
of what you
thinke behoofull, and to affourd my service
at reporte, as in your honorable Judgement
yow shall finde it doth deserve.
And so
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage
19 Oct
o
95
.
